professor john curtice , the psephologist , told the today programme earlier that , although the polls were converging , a no win still seemed more likely .
it 's close , but one also probably concludes that the odds on the no side winning are rather better than those on the yes side .
but , with a few days to go , i do n't think anyone would be wanting to put too much money on the outcome .
he also pointed out that half of scotland 's population did not vote in the 2011 scottish parliament elections , and that the vast majority of them were going to vote this time .

therefore , when the campaigns are thinking about how they are going to appeal to voters in the last few days , they need to bear in mind that probably the crucial audience does not consist of traditional labour voters , or people who have occasionally voted for the snp , but actually people who do n't have very much in the way of party loyalties at all .
for this group the crucial issue was whether or not they would be better off under independence , he said .

documents.title: afternoon summary
text: hundreds of yes supporters have taken part in a demonstration outside the bbc in glasgow to protest about alleged bbc bias .
the queen has reportedly said she hopes the scots think very carefully about the future '' before they vote , in what is being interpreted as confirmation that she wants scotland to stay in the uk .
buckingham palace said she took her duty to be impartial very seriously .
two senior figures in defence and diplomacy have declared their support for scottish independence .
as the press association reports , retired lieutenant commander colin may , a senior faslane naval intelligence officer , and former british ambassador donald maclaren have backed the yes campaign .
that 's all from me for today .
thanks for the comments .
here 's alex salmond with the singer amy macdonald , one of the perfomers at tonight 's yes scotland concert at the usher hall in edinburgh .
severin carrell ( @ severincarrell ) .
@ alexsalmond gets in with franz ferdinand & amy mcdonald at # usher hall for # voteyes night for scotland gig # indyref
here 's a short scottish independence referendum reading list .
mike small at bella caledonia says the british establishment has lost scotland .
what 's become clear is that the british establishment has lost scotland .
it 's over .
they might even still 'win ' , but they will have lost .
three fundamental ties have been broken : the bbc is now completely untrusted .
the labour party is finished .
the idea of a progressive british politics has gone .
a lot of the arguments has been about scottish politics , but what has happened here is people have looked south and seen a barren political landscape .
ed miliband ?
who ?
there is nothing there .

and when you begin to bring serious analysis from players about gender , class , ecology , powerlessness and potential , as a whole movement hs begun to do in the last year , the whole rotten edifice of britain looks utterly bankrupt .
they can 'shock and awe ' us all they like with threats from big business .
it wo n't change the fact that after the crash neither westminster politicians nor any of these figures have the credibility they think they do .
it 's like they are calling on ghosts of authority that have left us long ago .
these could be the last few days of britain .
kenan malik says independence may not provide the answers its supporters think it will .
whether an independent scotland would actually ditch austerity policies or create the health service that scots need is a moot point .
but the nationalist argument is a challenge as much to democracy as it is to tory policies .
if everyone always got the government they desired , democracy would be redundant .
we only need democracy because different people hold different views , and we often disagree with government policies .
the scots have , of course , a democratic right to vote for independence .
but to suggest that they should do because there is a conservative-led government at westminster seems fundamentally to misunderstand the nature and demands of democracy .
democracy puts the onus upon us to engage with people and to change their minds .

rather than create a movement that can challenge tory policies throughout the uk , however , proponents of scottish independence seek to create a new constituency that they think will be more amenable to their views .
an independent scotland will not solve the dilemma that democracy often creates governments with which a large proportion , even the majority , of the population disagree .
there is no single scottish view on any issue from abortion to iraq to independence .
scots , like the rest of the uk , are divided by class , culture , politics , gender , age and much else .
and , when it comes to politics and values , rather than a mythicised national identity , scots often have greater affinities with people in england than with fellow-scots .

as the comedian billy connolly has put it , 'i 've always remembered that i have a lot more in common with a welder from liverpool than i do with someone with an agricultural background from the highlands . '
tim johns on his blog explains when the results will come in .
a big yes rally has been taking place in edinburgh .
tam britton ( @ tambritton ) and another angle .
middle meadow walk , edinburgh .
# indyref evening news ( @ edinburghpaper ) # indyref campaigners out in force in the meadows .
mt @ twitterid : edinburgh .

documents.title: alastair campbell says anti-bbc protest is `` not far off putin ''
text: alastair campbell , tony blair 's former communications director , has described the anti-bbc protest as not far off putin '' .
alastair campbell ( @ campbellclaret ) had my run ins with bbc , but organised protests like the one going on now is beyond tebbit , and not far off putin .
vote yes for intimidation
here 's some more footage from the yes protest about alleged bbc bias .

winnie ewing , the 85-year-old former snp mp and winner of the hamilton byelection in 1967 ( seen as marking the moment snp started to emerge as a modern political force ) , is urging people to vote yes .
no supporters are lining up to form the word no at an edinburgh sports ground so it can be filmed from the air , my colleague ben quinn reports .
sir harry burns , scotland 's former chief medical officer , has spoken out in favour of a yes vote .
in an article in the sunday herald , he said staying in the uk would lead to greater inequality .
the comfortably off are misjudging the future if they think playing it safe is the way to go next week .
there is no status quo in our economic future .
the times are changing and the only choice is whether we want to be in control of our future or are we happy to hand it over to people who have shown they care little for the weak and the poor .
the policies being pursued by the uk government will widen inequality in our society and more and more of the middle classes will be caught on the wrong side of the divide .

documents.title: alex salmond says the bbc is biased
text: back to the bbc .
alex salmond has also been accusing the bbc of bias .
this is what he said in an interview with the sunday herald ( subscription ) when asked if the bbc was biased .
of course it is .
the problem with nick [ robinson ] i mean , do n't get me wrong , i like these folk , but they do n't realise they 're biased .
it 's the unconscious bias which is the most ­extraordinary thing of all .
if the bbc were covering , in my estimation , any referendum , in any democracy , anywhere in the world , they would cover it impeccably , in a balanced fashion .
what they do n't understand is they 're players in this .
salmond also made it clear that he was talking about the bbc 's london journalists , not people at bbc scotland .
i just think metropolitan bbc has found this whole thing extraordinarily difficult , to separate their own view of the world from their view reporting scotland .
alex salmond hackett/reuters

documents.title: better together poses five questions for undecided voters
text: better together is highlighting five key questions that it thinks undecided voters should ask .
for the record , here they are .
jobs - when so many businesses have said that they would be forced to move , are you certain that your job is safe ?
currency - do you know what the currency will be ?
pensions - are you sure your pension is safer in a separate scotland ?
prices - are you confident that prices in the shops wo n't go up ?
nhs - are you certain the nhs can be funded after separation ?
john reid , the labour former cabinet minister , has put out a statement highlighting these , and arguing in particular that only a no vote will save the nhs .
while we 're on the subject , here is what gordon brown is saying about the nhs in scotland in the no campaign speech he has been giving in scotland .
this recording is from the version he gave in the usher hall in edinburgh on friday night .

andrewsparrow ( @ andrewsparrow ) my new sounds : extract from gordon brown 's no stump speech , on salmond and nhs on # soundcloud this clip includes the bit where brown says that , if alex salmond continues to say he is powerless to save the nhs as first minister , he should make way for someone who can run the health service properly '' .
journalists who have heard this think that the former prime minister may have one g brown in mind as a candidate .
the usher hall event was being chaired by george galloway , who , despite being an old foe of brown 's , greeted him warmly and ended the evening saying he would like to see brown as first minister .
my colleague ben quinn has sent me more from john reid 's speech earlier .
( see 1.28pm . )
the former labour minister and mp john reid has accused scottish nationalists of seeking to tap into anti-english resentment by portraying themselves as 'team scotland ' in the referendum debate .

reid , who also accused his opponents of the fallacy '' of suggesting that scottishness of individuals was diminished if they engaged in something british , took aim directly at language used by scottish first minister alex salmond and other snp politicians .
we know what they meant by team westminster .

they mean english , '' said the former mp in a speech billed as an event to set out the positive case for scotland staying in the united kingdom.you can not build a decent fair prosperous scottish society on the basis of resentment against one of the nation 's inside that partnership . ''
he added : the essence of true patriotism is safeguarding the welfare of your people . ''

documents.title: yes campaigners protest about alleged bbc bias
text: yes campaigners really do n't like the bbc 's nick robinson .
michael deacon ( @ michaelpdeacon ) # positivity # optimism in fact , they are not keen on the bbc generally .
there is a large protest in glasgow now outside the bbc about the corporation 's alleged bias .
andrew browne ( @ repscotandrew ) thousand of people currently protesting against alleged bbc bias outside pacific quay studios in glasgow .
tom gordon ( @ scottishpol ) uws media prof john robertson tells anti-bbc bias protest that bbc `` demonise '' salmond .
he regularly says bbc are not objective there seems to be a live stream of it here .
and this wings over scotland article explains why many yes supporters think robinson lied about alex salmond last week .
robinson said salmond had refused to answer a question that he asked at the press conference .

i was there , and i thought it was fair enough because salmond refused to address the specific thrust of robinson 's question about why voters should trust him , a politician , rather than business leaders .
robinson obviously had the robin day question that prompted john nott walkout ( here today , and , if i may say so , a gone tomorrow politician '' etc ) in mind .
salmond did not address that trust point .
but i 've heard far worse examples of politcians dodging or evading questions , and salmond addressed the point about business concerns in general terms reasonably fully .

well , sort of .
she apparently delivered a platitude to someone in the crowd after church .
but it 's not hard to interpret ; no one has ever had her down as a yesser .

documents.title: lunchtime summary
text: political leaders in scotland and london have united to condemn the murder of the british aid worker david haines .

as david cameron chaired a meeting of the uk government 's cobra committee to consider his response , alex salmond took parallel action by chairing a resilience meeting '' - the scottish government 's equivalent .
but there have been differences in the policy positions they have advocated .
alex salmond has said the uk government anti-islamic state ( isis ) strategy should be clearer .
he was speaking about two hours before cameron used a lengthy statement in downing street to explain what the uk government 's anti-isis strategy was .
salmond also said that an independent scotland would only take military action against isis as part of a un-backed initiative .
cameron said the uk and its allies would be seeking un support for it strategy , but he has not made un support a pre-condition of air strikes .
nicola sturgeon , scotland 's deputy first minister , has said the snp is opposed to paying ransom for hostages .
this aligns the scottish government with the uk government 's position .

she said : i do not consider the paying of ransoms for hostages - while i totally understand the anguish of families - is the correct approach , because i think the danger is that it feeds rather than [ stops ] the whole act of hostage taking .
i think there is , widely , a real degree of scepticism to that approach .

salmond has said that , in the event of a no vote , he thinks there should not be another referendum for about 20 years - although he did not rule out a second referendum happening earlier under a different snp leader .
yes campaigners have welcomed an article from joseph stiglitz , the nobel prize-winning economist , saying the economic dangers of independence have been massively over-stated .
in an article in the sunday herald stiglitz wrote : there is , in fact , little basis for any of the forms of fear-mongering that have been advanced .
[ paul ] krugman , for instance , suggests that there are significant economies of scale : a small economy is likely , he seems to suggest , not to do well .
but an independent scotland will still be part of europe , and the great success of the eu is the creation of a large economic zone .
besides , even small political entities , like sweden , singapore , and hong kong have prospered , while much larger entities have not .
by an order of magnitude , far more important than size is the pursuit of the right policies .
another example of a non-issue is the currency .
there are many currency arrangements that would work .
scotland could continue using sterling john reid , the labour former scottish secretary , has said that if scots are n't sure about independence , they should vote no .
given that it is so close , if you genuinely do n't know , vote no .
the consequences if you do n't know , of voting yes , for ever .
this is n't the national lottery , we ca n't come back next week and say 'can i have another ticket ? ' .
it 's not like a warranty , you can say you tried it and it did n't work .
for goodness sake do n't gamble , the stakes are so high .
george galloway , the former labour mp , has said that if the uk breaks up , scottish labour will be primarily to blame .
lord dannatt , the former head of the army , has been criticised by both sides for saying a yes vote would dishonour the memory of british soldiers who died in northern ireland .
rupert murdoch has revealed that a trip to scotland over the weekend has left him no wiser as to who will win .
the pro-independence scottish greens have published figures saying oil companies receive around £ 1bn a year in tax breaks from the uk government .
patrick harvie , the co-convenor of the party , said the money could be better spent .

as scotland debates its future , discussion over oil has tended to focus on extracting every last drop and burning it , when we know we simply ca n't afford to do that for economic and environmental reasons .
what has also been overlooked is the huge subsidy we 're all giving the big oil companies .
now that figure 's out in the open we should consider the logic of continuing such massive tax breaks .
big oil companies are already throwing their weight around as the vote nears , and an independent scotland should be prepared to stand up to that .

if scotland remains part of the uk we will struggle to assert control ; with a yes we can build a genuinely sustainable economy , reducing our reliance on a declining industry and instead growing the clean technology of the future .
john reid has clarified that he meant people who do n't know should vote no when he was speaking earlier ( see 1.28pm ) , not that they should n't vote at all .
ben quinn ( @ benquinn75 ) john reid says it was a slip of the tongue in saying 'do n't vote if you do n't know ' .
he says 'vote no if you do n't know ' # indyref
according to the mail on sunday , ed balls , the shadow chancellor has raised concerns about the plans to give scotland more tax-raising powers in the event of a no vote .

ed balls has raised fears that handing massive new tax-raising powers to scotland - as suggested by gordon brown - could mean big trouble for a future labour government at a behind-closed-doors meeting of labour 's shadow cabinet held the following day , mr balls warned of grave implications for an incoming labour government if mr brown 's plan went ahead .
mr balls said : 'if we give away the whole tax-raising power to the scottish parliament , how can scottish labour mps then vote for a labour budget in england ? '

currently , 40 of the 59 scottish mps are labour , with pollsters predicting mr miliband will need a sizeable scottish contingent at westminster to form a government with a workable commons majority after the general election next may .
a witness at the meeting said : 'it was clear what balls was saying .
'he was wondering out loud how we would get budgets passed at westminster without scottish labour votes .
it 'd be a nightmare . '
mr miliband had no answer to his shadow chancellor 's concerns , according to reports .
my colleague ben quinn has been listening to john reid , the labour former cabinet minister , speaking in edinburgh .

ben quinn ( @ benquinn75 ) john reid : if you genuinely do n't know then do n't vote in scotland 's # indyref 'this is not the national lottery ' ben quinn ( @ benquinn75 ) john reid `` there are 1000 ways to make a protest vote .

gambling with your country 's future is not the most sensible way of doing it # indyref update at 1.50pm : ben quinn ( @ benquinn75 ) john reid says it was a slip of the tongue in saying 'do n't vote if you do n't know ' .
he says 'vote no if you do n't know ' # indyref

the gmb union has announced that it is going to hold a protest in glasgow on tuesday about snp-led dundee council 's decision to propose offering a £ 45m contract to a firm implicated in the blacklisting scandal .
this is not directly related to the referendum , but the timing seems designed to undermine the yes camp .
the gmb are protesting outside nicola sturgeon 's constituency office in glasgow , on the grounds that she is responsible for construction procurement policy in scotland .
the gmb wants her and alex salmond to intervene with dundee council .

documents.title: galloway says , if uk breaks up , scottish labour will be primarily to blame
text: george galloway , the former labour mp who now represents respect and who is campaigning prominently for a no vote , told the bbc 's sunday politics that he would have a very great deal to say '' about how poor the better together campaign has been after the result on friday .
he was particularly critical of the scottish labour party .
scottish labour is potentially on its death bed and if the country breaks up , the principle responsibility will be on them .

from the blair era onwards , the iraq war , the collapse in credibility and confidence in the british state , not just in scotland but through farage and so on in the rest of the country , the pitiful , absolutely pitiful , job that 's been made of defending a 300-year-old relationship in this island by the scottish labour leadership is really terrible for me to behold , even though i 'm no longer one of them without a doubt the number of labour voters intending to vote yes is disturbingly high .
that 's a grave squandering of a great legacy of scottish labour history which history will decree as unpardonable , unforgivable .
now , if labour is to get out of its deathbed in scotland , whatever the result , it 's going to have to become labour again - real labour again .
i 'm ready to help them with that and my goodness they need help with it .
reading that final sentence , it sounds like galloway is quite keen to rejoin .
i 've taken the quote from politicshome .
george galloway carson/pa

documents.title: lord dannatt criticised for saying voting yes would dishonour memory of dead soldiers
text: lord dannatt , the former head of the army , has been criticised this morning for suggesting that voting yes in the scottish referendum would dishonour the memory of british soldiers who died in northern ireland .
he made the argument in an article in the sunday telegraph .
he wrote : do the families of scottish soldiers who lost their lives between 1969 and 2007 to preserve the territorial integrity of the united kingdom now just say , well , it no longer matters '' ?

i can not speak for them , but i wonder just how much thought , appreciation and recognition is given to the memory of those who have fought and brought this united kingdom of ours to where it is today , and where it could be in the future .
and i really worry on behalf of the wives , mothers and friends of those scottish soldiers who died to keep northern ireland in the united kingdom .

i worry particularly about the extent that we will be letting them down if scotland disappears from our country , just on the whim of a few thousand voters willing to gamble on an uncertain future rather than staying within the united kingdom , whose track record is second to none in europe .
douglas alexander , the shadow foreign secretary and a leading figure in the no campaign , told sky news that dannatt was wrong .
i am unyielding in my admiration and respect for the men and women of the british armed forces and the contribution that scots have played and continue to play in those forces .

but many british soldiers have given their lives over the years to defeat fascism and then to defend democracy and let 's be absolutely clear : what we are witnessing here in scotland on thursday is an exercise in democracy .
so i hold no brief for lord dannatt this morning .
and nicola sturgeon , scotland 's deputy first minister , said dannatt 's comments bordered on being offensive and insulting '' on the same programme .
there are mixed opinions across the armed forces as there are across scottish society .
lord dannatt scarff/getty images

documents.title: what the scottish sunday papers are saying about independence - summary and analysis
text: all the sunday papers in scotland have expressed their views on independence today .
the scottish press , like the uk press , is overwhelmingly pro-union , but there are surprising differences in the level of enthusiasm they show for a no vote .
only one is backing yes .
my colleague severin carrell has been looking at what they have been saying and assessing their decision .
here 's his analysis .

today 's sunday papers have given their verdict on the vote , with only the sunday herald declaring itself again for yes , some five months after coming out in favour of independence in its bold front page stating that the prize is a better country . ''
with the sunday mail and sun on sunday the only two papers to suggest they remain neutral , the observer offers a very cautious but highly qualified endorsement of a union in need of change .

urging a root and branch renewal of the broken '' uk , the observer argues : given scotland 's historic attachment to values of social solidarity and its capacity to produce leaders and thinkers of talent and distinction , it would be all the more compelling to think that scotland would be part of this renewal .
that londoners , mancunians and glaswegians will work together to re-make britain in such a way that all its regions are empowered , and all its people written firmly and fairly into a new union .
a new political settlement for the union offers a convincing opportunity of a new start for the whole of britain .
on thursday , scotland will decide but , whatever that choice , britain will not be , and should not be , the same again . ''

the sunday post , one of scotland 's most famous and distinctive papers , and home for oor wullie and the broons , puts its appeal for a no vote boldly on the front page , reminding its readers that it too is an institution : the sunday post is as scottish as haggis and maw broon 's tartan shawl . ''

paying tribute to the yes campaign and alex salmond for bringing the nation 's concerns to the fore and finally woken up westminster to the anger and power of the disenfranchised , '' it says it readers should accept the offer of more powers from the uk parties .
it states : we do n't need to be separate to achieve change .
[ the ] collective strength of the uk has allowed us to be a powerful economic force on the world stage .
that umbrella , that safety net , that success story , is too important to easily cast aside . ''
the sunday mail , stablemate of the often pro-labour daily record , has veered towards suggesting a yes vote is acceptable , arguing that scotland will survive whatever the electorate decide .

it rains down criticism of the pro-uk better together dismal '' campaign , accusing it of baffling complacency '' , and seeing only a bleak and terrible blackness rolling over an independent scotland .

arguing that yes voters are a justified in seeing the referendum as a protest vote against the westminster government , it states : offer people the chance to clean out the stables , vote for dramatic change in the hope of a dramatically different kind of politics and they decide to take it ?
who could have predicted that ? ''
but it fails to offer a definitive opinion on how to vote , concludes simply : yes or no , scotland is moving on to where we are meant to be .
and you know what ?
we 'll be fine . ''

scotland on sunday has followed its sister paper the scotsman by urging a no vote , arguing that the extra powers on offer from the uk parties will give holyrood the toolkit to build the country we all want to live in . ''

it notes that the scottish national party 's policies on independence actually involve surrendering large areas of sovereignty , on currency and monetary policy to the bank of england , its defence to nato and to brussels with eu membership .
sos says that the vote on thursday boils down to how scotland shares power .
it states that a no vote is actually a vote for much greater devolution , not the status quo .
our scotland is a tremendous country .
ambitious , audacious , brimful of ideas .
flawed , certainly , and sometimes infuriating .
but its flaws are our flaws and we have no-one to blame for them except ourselves .
they are not the fault of the english .
they are not the fault of westminster .
they are the product of our own failings , and failures to act .
the powers we have at the moment , strengthened with the powers promised , give us the toolkit we need to build a better future for ­scotland , if we have the will .
but first we have to choose to go forward not as two scottish tribes but as one scottish nation .
scotland united , within a united kingdom . ''
the mail on sunday 's scottish edition devotes an entire page its robust editorial appeal to vote no with the headline : we built this great nation together .
to walk away now would diminish every one of us . ''

arguing that divorce is an expensive and unpleasant business from which few parties ever emerge with their dignity and decency intact , '' it concludes : when scots go to the polls on thursday , they should vote no , appreciating that this is a vote for a scotland confident enough to resist the illusory blandishments of an impossible nationalist nirvana . ''
the sun on sunday refuses to take a side , despite rupert murdoch 's delight in goading david cameron on twitter about the yes campaign 's surge in support .
it states : both camps say their [ polling ] figures tell them they have victory in the bag .
but there is only one winner and by the time you read your next scottish sun on sunday , scotland will either be independent - or it wo n't .
quebec have [ sic ] been there and done it and have been left scarred in the process .
we ca n't let that happen to scotland - whatever the outcome . ''
however its stable mate the sunday times urges a no vote , arguing that a vote for independence on thursday that led to the break-up of britain 'would be a profound tragedy '' .
it concludes : thursday 's vote should be more than just heart versus head .
patriotism is not wrapping yourself in the saltire and becoming an inward looking and angry country which happens to be attached to england .
true patriotism for scots should be a vote for the union to which they have made an enormous contribution and whose loss would diminish both them and the world . ''

the staunchly unionist sunday telegraph repeatedly quotes the former defence chief lord dannatt in its leader , after splashing the paper with an emotive story about the sacrifice of british troops on the union 's behalf .
it states that our future can be great if we face it together , '' arguing : what was their sacrifice for ?
they died fighting in the service of a political union that has brought law and order , democracy and relative stability to these islands for hundreds of years .

it is a union bound by a common language expressed in poetry that captures in sound and rhythm a countryside as splendidly variant as its people : from the prim gardens of kent to the audacious dunvegan castle that seems cut from the hebridean rock . ''
the sunday express insists that most scots have a gut instinct '' in favour of staying in the uk .

it stretches credulity by insisting it has not arrived lightly '' at its decision to back the union , but concludes : on thursday , this quiet army of ordinary scots , decent folk who have kept their counsel and not shoved their views down everybody else 's throat , must finally make their voices heard .
nobody should be in any doubt about what is at stake .
whatever you do on september 18 , no matter how busy you are , you must vote in this referendum .
alex salmond says this is a lucky generation and we agree - we have been given the chance to save the united kingdom .
let us grasp it with both hands . ''

documents.title: salmond/darling interviews - full summary
text: here 's a fuller summary of the alex salmon/alistair darling interviews , with the key quotes .
salmond suggested that the uk government 's anti-isis strategy should be clearer .

it would be , i think , useful if a strategy and a policy were developed because there has been - i 'm talking about generalities , not specific to any hostage in terms of the overall attitude to iraq , famously the president of the united states says 'i 'm going to develop a strategy ' .
i think a strategy is urgently required .
he said that the scottish government would be holding a resilience meeting '' this morning to discuss its response to the murder of david haines .
it is the scottish equivalent of the cobra committee being chaired by david cameron , he said .
he said it was important for the scottish government to hold communities together '' in the light of events in the middle east .
it is 'very important in these difficult international times that we hold our communities together .
for example , the muslim community of scotland is n't responsible in any shape or form for atrocities or extremism in iraq or elsewhere .
it 's very , very important .
just like , a few weeks ago , the jewish community in scotland was n't responsible for the policies of the state of israel .
now , thankfully we have strong communities .
he did not explicity rule out an independent scottish government paying for the release of hostages , although he said you ca n't have a situation where you bow to terrorism '' .
he also said he supported what the foreign office had done to try to secure haines ' release .
you ca n't have a situation where terrorism influences policy and strategy , '' he said .
subsequently , on sky news , , nicola sturgeon , salmond 's deputy , did explicitly out paying ransom for hostages .
salmond reaffirmed that an independent scotland would only support military action against isis as part of an international effort .
there should be collective action under the un , he said .
countries like china and russia would support this , he claimed .
he said he thought thursday 's vote should settle the referendum issue for a generation , which he defined as being a period of about 20 years .
but he did not explicitly rule out there being another referendum earlier in the event of a no vote .
if you remember that previous constitutional referendum in scotland - there was one in 1979 and then the next one was 1997 .
that 's what i mean by a political generation .
in my opinion , and it is just my opinion , this is a once in a generation opportunity for scotland .
asked if he could pledge not to bring back another referendum if the yes campaign does not win on thursday , he replied : that 's my view .
my view is this is a once in a generation , perhaps even a once in a lifetime , opportunity for scotland .
that implies that an snp government could hold another referendum sooner , under a different leader .
darling said he also thought the referendum should settle the matter for a generation .
salmond said there had been idiots '' on both sides of the campaign , but he said aggressive behaviour was confined to a very small minority .

salmond said : listen , the idiots on both sides are a microcosm , a tiny , tiny wee percentage ; 99.9 % of campaigners on both sides are engaging in the most invigorating , empowering enjoyable debate ; not just in scottish democratic history , i 've seen nothing like this in western europe , certainly in recent generations .
darling implied that the leaders of the yes campaign had not done enough to rein in their abusive supporters .
darling refused to give explicit details of what powers would be devolved to scotland in the event of a no vote under the deal agreed by the three main uk parties .
but there would definitely be a deal , he said .

of course we 've high regard for each other ''
that 's over .
alex salmond made the better impression , i felt .
alistair darling was particularly negative , and he was evasive on the subject of what extra powers scotland would get in the event of a no vote .
i 'll post a summary shortly .
alex salmond and alistair darling are now being interviewed together .
q : [ to salmond ] have you flinched at anything during the campaign ?
salmond says there have been incidents involving him .
there are idiots '' on both side .
they are a microcosm .
q : and scotland must have the best educated population in the world .
i hope so , says darling .
it has been energising .
q : how do you regard each other ?
salmond says darling is a first-rate politician .
he would have a place in salmond 's negotiating team .
darling says of course he has high regard for salmond .
q : in the sunday times you say it has been a dark and menacing campaign .
have you been menaced ?
yes , says darling .
he has never seen anything like this in 35 years .
yesterday he was somewhere where he was shouted down just for being there .
and look at what has happened on the internet .
q : are you saying this is coming from the top ?
darling says there have been problems on both sides .
but , on his side , when anyone steps over the line , that is dealt with .
he implies that has not been the case on the other said .
q : what is your reaction to the death of david haines ?
it is appalling news , he says .
the whole world will be offering condolences , he says .
darling says there is no argument for extending the life of this parliament .
the general election will go ahead in may .
he thinks no will win .
q : why ?
because scotland wo n't get bullied into accepting something it does not want , he says .
it sounds like salmond versus scotland .
scotland will win .
q : but if it 's close , this will come back .
scotland is in a process .
darling says he does not accept that .
nationalism ebbs and flows '' .
he agrees with salmond that this should be settled for a generation .
no one wants to go through another two-year referendum .
q : if there is a yes vote , there will have to be a currency deal quickly .
darling says the problem is that this would not be in the interests of scotland or the rest of the uk .
he does not want to see his country subjected to years of uncertainty , he says .
q : this sounds like scaremongering .
what we have n't had is a passionate defence of britain .
darling says he does not accept that .
the scots helped build the uk .
it is a huge thing that has been achieved .
voting no would avoid the risks coming from the uncertainty .
we do n't know the answer to fundamental questions raised by independence , he says .

documents.title: alistair darling 's interview on the andrew marr show
text: andrew marr is now interviewing alistair darling .
darling says he always thought it would be close .
q : when will we see details of the extra powers being offered scotland ?
darling says an independent scotland would get more powers over tax .
q : will we see details ?
darling says what has been agreed is the timetable .
that process will start on friday if there 's a no vote .
scots want the nhs safeguarded .
there would be certainty over pensions too .
q : it sounds like there is n't a deal .
labour 's views are not the same as the tories ' , or the lib dems ' .
darling says before 1997 the parties came together .
the only party that did not was the snp .
there will be a deal , he says .
there is absolute clarity '' as far as strengthening the scottish parliament is concerned , he says .
salmond was doing a premature victory lap '' in his interview , he says .
q : would an independent scotland be able to choose its own head of state ?
salmond says most scots want the queen to be queen of scots , and her successors to carry on as monarch too .
q : so can you rule out a referendum ?
salmond says a yougov poll recently showed a substantial majority in favour of the monarchy .
prince charles is greatly loved in scotland , he says .
q : so that 's a pledge ?
salmond says , as first minister , that is his judgement .
he wants to see the queen as queen of scots .
q : are you concerned about the eu/us free trade deal , and its impact on the nhs ?
salmond says this is an important issue .
he thinks the nhs should be excluded .
this is a good reason for being independent .
q : but you want to join the eu , and the eu favours this pact ?
salmond says countries can refuse to open up their health sector to private providers .
the problem arises if they have already opened it up to private providers , he says .
q : would scotland have to rejoin the eu ?
salmond says scotland would still be in the eu .
he thinks the negotiation could be concluded within 18 months ( ie , before independence takes effect ) .
and he rebukes marr for using the word separation .
john bercow did not allow that in commons legislation because it 's pejorative , he says .
q : scotland would still be under the thumb of the bank of england .
salmond says it 's the bank for england , scotland wales and northern ireland .
q : would you accept their fiscal rules ?
salmond says the bank does not set fiscal rules .
there would be a fiscal agreement , covering things like borrowing and debt .
he predicts that there will be common sense agreements '' on a currency union after friday .
salmond cites an article from joseph stiglitz in today 's papers .
he says a shared currency would be very viable , and it would be a common sense thing to do .
q : what would you do after a victory ?
go to the ryder cup the following week , jokes salmond .
there would be a job of bringing scotland together , he says .
he says alistair carmichael , the lib dem scottish secretary , has said he would join the scottish government 's negotiating team .
johann lamont has hinted she would too , he says .
he would also want to involve scottish civil society .
they have knowledge of things to be negotiated .
salmond says he is presuming nothing .
but , if there is a yes vote , salmond would give a strong and early indication '' of how team scotland would move forward .
salmond says there should be early decisions .
for 18 months , the bank of england would remain in control .
now marr turns to the referendum .
q : if it 's a no vote by a whisker , is that it ?
does it settle it for a generation ?
yes , says salmond .
he cites the gap betweeen 1979 and 1997 .
that 's what he means by generation , he says .
q : so you wo n't bring it back for another 20 years .
that 's my view , says salmond .

today 's campaign events will be overshadowed by the murder of the british/scottish aid worker david haines by islamic state ( isis ) .
alex salmond has said the release of the video showing the beheading demonstrated a degree of brutality which defies description '' .
david cameron , who described it as an act of pure evil '' , is holding an emergency meeting in number 10 and his planned trip to scotland tomorrow could now be abandoned .
so far , in news reports , i 've seen no attempt to link the killing of haines with the referendum .
but it seems at least reasonable to ask if the video was released now with the intention of influencing the campaign .

islamist extremists have already had an impact on the result of at least one western election through a terror attack ( in madrid ) and part of salmond 's argument for independence is that it would stop scotland being dragged into reckless intervention in the middle east .

by the end of the day i 'd be surprised if this issue is not being debated a bit more in public .
